lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can actively listen and identify key characters and toys mentioned in the story.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Before audio, point to story characters/toys and ask: “Who’s this?” / “What is it?”
stretchStrategies: After acting out the story, ask students to draw their own version of the ending. Volunteers use the story characters to describe: “The robot plays with the teddy.”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read the story, act it out and then answer questions using the target language.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Read and act out the story. Students echo lines and gesture.
stretchStrategies: After acting out the story, ask students to draw their own version of the ending. Volunteers use the story characters to describe: “The robot plays with the teddy.”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can create a simple, imaginative ending to the story orally or visually.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Creativity) Show last image in story. Ask: “What happens next?” Students say one sentence each.
stretchStrategies: After acting out the story, ask students to draw their own version of the ending. Volunteers use the story characters to describe: “The robot plays with the teddy.”

items: VYL: colours do not map onto one another (blue/green = blue)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
